content: Precondition You already have a GitLab (GitLab Saas or GitLab self managed). This document is for .NET 4.X, if you want to build .NET core or .NET 5/6/7/‚Ä¶, you can use docker to run GitLab Runner.
title: Use GitLab to do .NET 4.X CI/CD

content: Step 1 - Install Git client Download and install Git for Windows. Portable version is ok, but because Git Runner is a Windows service, please add git.exe into PATH.
title: Use GitLab to do .NET 4.X CI/CD

content: Step 2 - prepare .NET build environment Download and install Visual Studio. (Please let me know if I can build a .NET build environment without Visual Studio, thanks.)
title: Use GitLab to do .NET 4.X CI/CD

content: Step 3 - Install GitLab Runner Download GitLab Runner Rename gitlab-runner-windows-amd64.exe to gitlab-runner.exe Get the token to run GitLab Runner Generate GitLab Runner configuration file (config.toml) Run the command gitlab-runner.exe register ‚Äìurl https://gitlab.com/ ‚Äìregistration-token $REGISTRATION_TOKEN Modify config.toml Because Gitlab Runner doesn‚Äôt suppoer Windows shell after version 13, you need to use PowerShell. If you use Power Shell, please open config.toml and rename ‚Äòpwsh‚Äô to ‚Äòpowershell‚Äô. (If you use Power Shell Core, you don‚Äôt need to do anything) If you use a portable Git, you need to modify $env:Path of PowerShell. If you find your log is garbled (ex: your Windows server is not English version), please add ‚Äúchcp 65001‚Äù to change the encoding to UTF-8. Register GitLab Runner as a Windows service and start it. Run the command gitlab-runner install to install as a Windows service. Run the command gitlab-runner start to start the service. config.toml sample => remember, if you modify the file, please execute gitlab-runner.exe restart to restart GitLab runner. concurrent = 1check_interval = 0[session_server]session_timeout = 1800[[runners]]name = "GitLab Runner 007"url = "https://gitlab.com/"token = "******************"executor = "shell"shell = "powershell"pre_clone_script = """chcp 65001$env:Path += ";C:\\Gitlab\\PortableGit\\cmd""""[runners.custom_build_dir][runners.cache][runners.cache.s3][runners.cache.gcs][runners.cache.azure]If you always see the Credential Helper Selector, please choose ‚Äúno helper‚Äù and ‚ÄúAlways use this from now on‚Äù.
title: Use GitLab to do .NET 4.X CI/CD

content: Step 4 - Write .gitlab-ci.yml Edit .gitlab-ci.yml, the following is a sample: stages:- build- testbuild:stage: buildscript:- "dotnet build"artifacts:paths:- .\testtest:stage: testscript: - "dotnet test"
title: Use GitLab to do .NET 4.X CI/CD

content: Step 5 - Start to build/test/deploy code (local machine) Change directory to the location of .gitlab-ci.yml and execute this command gitlab-runner.exe exec shell build
title: Use GitLab to do .NET 4.X CI/CD

content: Step 6 - Start to test CI/CD (local machine) If everything is ok, you can commit .gitlab-ci.yml and GitLab should run it automatically.
title: Use GitLab to do .NET 4.X CI/CD

content: SAST (Static Application Security Testing) GitLab can check your source code for known vulnerabilities, unfortunately, it only support Linux container, Windows containers are not yet supported. (reference: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/)
title: Use GitLab to do .NET 4.X CI/CD

content: Purpose When we commit code to GitLab, we want GitLab sends the code to [Checkmarx] (https://checkmarx.com/) to scan. (the next step is to integrate the scan result to SonarQube)
title: GitLab Checkmarx integration

content: Procedure You can reference official document: https://checkmarx.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SD/pages/1929937052/GitLab+Integration Edit .gitlab-ci.yml include: 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/checkmarx-ltd/cx-flow/develop/templates/gitlab/v3/Checkmarx.gitlab-ci.yml'variables:CX_PROJECT: ProjectXXX #The project name you want to show in CheckmarxEdit GitLab CI/CD variables Please remember to set GITLAB_URL and GITLAB_TOKEN, then Checkmarx will create GitLab issue for Checkmarx issues. Trigger build - Checkmarx analysis will be triggered when you create a merge request or you commit to master stream directly. Suggest to use pure English for CX_TEAM, if you use non English (ex: Chinese), you can check the log and find it cannot find the team. 2022-01-12 02:51:22.748 INFO 11 --- [main] c.c.s.s.CxService [x4DNMhOL] : Found team /CxServer/Team1 with ID 16During the analysis, you can check the status from Checkmarx, it takes long time to analyze. After the analysis, you can check the result in Checkmarx. You can also check it from GitLab, it generates 1 report in merge request and it will create issues by category. The following is the reqport of merge request. In the above report, there are 5 issues, it will creates 5 issues by file/by category. In the issue, it shows the detail vulnerability information.
title: GitLab Checkmarx integration

content: image.png image.png
title: GitLab Checkmarx SonarQube integration

content: Purpose When we commit code to GitLab, we want GitLab to trigger these actions automatically: GitLab sends the code to Checkmarx to scan. GitLab triggers SonarQube to sacn. SonarQube integrate Checkmarx‚Äôs report.
title: GitLab Checkmarx SonarQube integration

content: Procedure You can reference the official document: https://checkmarx.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SD/pages/169246832/SonarQube+Plugin+v8.5.0+and+up Download the plugin from here, it only supports SonarQube LTS version (for now, it‚Äôs 8.x) Configurea Quality Gate/Profiles of SonarQube for Checkmarx‚Äôs rules. Use GitLab to trigger Checkmarx scan and record the project name of Checkmarx. Configure Checkmarx data in SonarQube, you can reference here. Trigger GitLab CI again, you will see the following log in your SonarQube job INFO: Sensor Import Checkmarx scan results to SonarQube [checkmarx]INFO: Retrieving Checkmarx scan results for current module [Checkmarx plugin version: 2021.2.1]INFO: Getting Checkmarx configuration data from sonar Database.INFO: Resolving Cx setting: checkmarx.server.project_nameINFO: Forced authentication is enabled: Sonar credentials must be providedINFO: Sonar server token is providedINFO: Checkmarx credentials migration not neededINFO: Sonar server token is providedINFO: Resolving Cx setting: checkmarx.server.project_nameINFO: Forced authentication is enabled: Sonar credentials must be providedINFO: Checkmarx server version [9.2.0.41015]. Hotfix [24].INFO: Logging into the Checkmarx service.INFO: Connecting to https://your.checkmarx.server/INFO: Initializing Cx client [2020.2.4.NO.SCA]INFO: Checkmarx server version [9.2.0.41015]. Hotfix [24].INFO: Logging into the Checkmarx service.INFO: full team path: \CxServer\\Team1INFO: preset name: AllINFO: ---------------------------------Get Last CxSAST Results:--------------------------------INFO: Waiting for server to generate xml report. 4990 seconds left to timeoutINFO: Checkmarx High vulnerabilities: 3INFO: Checkmarx New-High vulnerabilities: 0INFO: Checkmarx Medium vulnerabilities: 23INFO: Checkmarx New-Medium vulnerabilities: 1INFO: Checkmarx Low vulnerabilities: 142INFO: Checkmarx New-Low vulnerabilities: 7INFO: Checkmarx scan link: https://your.checkmarx.server//CxWebClient/ViewerMain.aspx?scanId=1000157&ProjectID=67You can see the Checkmarx issues in SonarQube now.
title: GitLab Checkmarx SonarQube integration
